newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan parties seen agreeing on holding companies.
newsitem.headline: Japan parties seen agreeing on holding companies.

text.p: Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) and its allies are expected to reach an agreement on Thursday on lifting a decades-long ban on holding companies, an official at a trade watchdog said on Wednesday.

An agreement between the LDP, the Social Democratic Party and the small Sakigake party would enable the government to work out necessary changes to Japan's anti-monopoly law and submit them to the current session of parliament by March 11, the Fair Trade Commission (FTC) official said.

The FTC, Japan"s anti-monopoly watchdog, has drawn up proposed changes to the law that would allow the establishment of certain types of holding companies, overturning a ban imposed by U.S. Occupation forces after World War Two.
Holding companies are firms which control one or more other firms, often by holding a majority stake in them, but do not themselves engage in a specific business.

"Without reaching an agreement, it is difficult to finalise the necessary legal revisions, get approval by the cabinet and submit the bill to parliament on March 11," the official said. "We expect the parties will reach agreement on Thursday."
If submitted after March 11, the legislation could not be passed in the current session.

The official, who did not want to be identified, said the revised anti-monopoly law should take effect early in 1998 but declined to be more specific. The parties are expected to agree on the outline proposed by the FTC.
U.S. Occupation forces introduced the ban on holding companies in 1947 to break up powerful conglomerates known as "zaibatsu" which the United States believed had contributed to Japan"s war effort.
But big businesses and banks have demanded that the ban be lifted to help them streamline and compete with overseas rivals.
Under the draft legislation recently worked out by the FTC, three types of holding companies will continue to be banned to avoid an excessive concentration of business strength.
The three include extremely large corporate groups, corporate groups headed by a large financial institution and groups formed by leading firms in the same or related industries.
